summary: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York today announced criminal charges against Ricky Ricardo Mancilla-Ibarra.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Jackson, Mississippi, alleges that, during a sting operation conducted by the Drug Enforcement Administration, officers observed a white van with Georgia tags approach Fann's home and pulled through the open gate on the side of the house.  According to the complaint, the van was accompanied by a man named “Benny,” who provided officers with information about the source of the drug.  As alleged in the SEC complaint, however, the driver of the van did not cooperate with the officers' search of the home.  Instead, the complaint alleges, the officers conducted a controlled buy of methamphetamine with the intent to arrest the driver, who was later convicted of conspiracy to possess and distribute the drug with intent to distribute.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney’s Office for New Jersey today filed criminal charges in federal district court for the southern district of New Jersey.  On May 15, 2016, officers stopped Fann for running a stop sign and arrested him without a warrant.  During the search, officers uncovered three kilograms of pre-packaged, ready-to-distribution methamphetamine hidden in his wall and showed the officers where in the wall it was hidden.  After the arrest, officers asked Fann to come forward and tell the officers that he had never bought more than one kilogram of methamphetamine at a time from Benny, and the officers asked him to set up a sting with a buyer he identified.  Fann agreed to the officers’ request for a two-level reduction because he had provided the officers with a reasonable basis to believe he had made a successful delivery of the drugs.  Without admitting or denying the allegations of the SEC, the defendants consented to the entry of a final judgment that permanently enjoins them from future violations of the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and orders them to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains with prejudgment interest, civil penalties, and officer-and-director bars.  Finally, the court granted the SEC's motion for a temporary restraining order and a preliminary injunction against further violations of Section 5C1.2(a)(5) and Rule 5a-3 thereunder and ordered the officers to pay a civil penalty of 135 months of imprisonment.   The court also denied the request for an injunction against future violations, and issued an order prohibiting the officers from
